attributes.title: How Social Group Endorsement by Partisan Elites Influences Affective Polarization

q1.value: How Social Group Endorsement by Partisan Elites Influences Affective Polarization

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Political parties have the ability to influence public opinion formation (Druckman at al. 2013, Slothuus and deVrees 2010) and even the way citizens interpret complex reality (Bisgaard and Slothuus 2018). Do party cues priming social group endorsement influence voters’ attitudes? This experiment sets out to examine how social group (LGBT people/White Evangelicals) endorsement by elite partisans is able to shape: Partisan affect Social group (LGBT people/White Evangelicals) affection

q16.value: H1: Social group endorsement by the out-party increases out-party affection among supporters of the party traditionally associated with the social group. H2: Social group endorsement by the out-party increases social group affection among out-party supporters H3: Social group endorsement by the out-party increases percieved discrimination against the social group H4: social group endorsement by the out-party increases political trust among supporters of the party traditionally associated with the social group

q17.value: We will conduct difference-in-means and difference-in-proportions, in addition to regression analysis. We will conduct the analysis both with the entire sample of respondents and with sub-samples of respondents based on party identification, sexual orientation and religious identity.

registration_responses.q1: How Social Group Endorsement by Partisan Elites Influences Affective Polarization
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment
registration_responses.q15: Political parties have the ability to influence public opinion formation (Druckman at al. 2013, Slothuus and deVrees 2010) and even the way citizens interpret complex reality (Bisgaard and Slothuus 2018). Do party cues priming social group endorsement influence voters’ attitudes? This experiment sets out to examine how social group (LGBT people/White Evangelicals) endorsement by elite partisans is able to shape: Partisan affect Social group (LGBT people/White Evangelicals) affection
registration_responses.q16: H1: Social group endorsement by the out-party increases out-party affection among supporters of the party traditionally associated with the social group. H2: Social group endorsement by the out-party increases social group affection among out-party supporters H3: Social group endorsement by the out-party increases percieved discrimination against the social group H4: social group endorsement by the out-party increases political trust among supporters of the party traditionally associated with the social group
registration_responses.q17: We will conduct difference-in-means and difference-in-proportions, in addition to regression analysis. We will conduct the analysis both with the entire sample of respondents and with sub-samples of respondents based on party identification, sexual orientation and religious identity.

attributes.title: GOTV Within Social Networks: An Experiment Conducted During the 2019 Elections

q1.value: GOTV Within Social Networks: An Experiment Conducted During the 2019 Elections

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: We use a randomized controlled trial (RCT) to evaluate the effects of a distributed voter mobilization drive in which “captains” in several sites around the country encouraged turnout among people they know. The results from this study will help future researchers to design and implement social network based mobilization efforts.

q16.value: The principal hypothesis is that when a potential voter receives personal encouragement to vote from a friend or relative, she will be more likely to vote.

q17.value: Random assignment was conducted with blocks defined by each captain’s proposed list of friends/relatives. Approximately half the subjects in each list were randomly assigned to the treatment group, for a total of 424 treatment subjects and 419 control subjects. Eight subjects were present on multiple lists and therefore had a greater chance of being assigned to treatment than other subjects. To reflect variation in probability of treatment assignment, we will use inverse probability weighting per the “Duplicate records in the dataset used for randomization” section of the Green Lab SOP. We will compare (weighted) turnout rates in treatment and control.

q27.value: The intervention was conceived and implemented by a third party. Researchers were responsibly only for the randomization and data analysis.

registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

The results from this study will help future researchers to design and implement social network based mobilization efforts.

Eight subjects were present on multiple lists and therefore had a greater chance of being assigned to treatment than other subjects. To reflect variation in probability of treatment assignment, we will use inverse probability weighting per the “Duplicate records in the dataset used for randomization” section of the Green Lab SOP. We will compare (weighted) turnout rates in treatment and control.

attributes.title: How the arrival of asylum seekers affects local politics in municipalities: the case of Finnish politicians and VAA survey responses

q1.value: How the arrival of asylum seekers affects local politics in municipalities: the case of Finnish politicians and VAA survey responses

q5.value: This study has been generously funded by the Ella and Georg Ehrnrooth foundation as well as the Finnish Konkordia League.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Although there is a correlation that is easily established in today’s political landscape in Europe between increasing immigration from Africa and the Middle-East due to the 2015 refugee crisis and the surge in support for far-right and anti-immigration parties, it is hard to establish the causal mechanism at work due to confounding factors as well as due to lack of micro-level data that could permit causal inferences. The empirical analysis providing causal evidence for this puzzle has yielded partially contradicting results: Steinmayr (2016) established a decrease in the votes for the far-right in the geographic vicinity to asylum seekers in Austria whereas Dinas et al. (2018) showed an increase in the vote share for the Greek far right as a result of direct exposure to refugees. Instead of focusing just on voters, this article examines the political elite in Finland: what type of candidates run for office and how do candidates in municipal elections formulate their campaign promises and preferences for immigration and redistributive policies, and how do they answer questions on social values depending on their level of exposure to asylum seekers?

q16.value: The aim of this study is to empirically measure the impact of exposure to asylum seekers on political parties and their candidates. In particular, I will examine if candidates change their stances on immigration and the welfare state in districts with asylum seekers’ reception centres and how much electoral reward there is for such stance shifts. The central idea is to test whether it is contact theory (Allport 1954) or conflict theory (Collins 1974) at work, that is, do politicians become more compassionate or exclusive in their campaign promises in the geographical vicinity to refugees as well as how the composition of party lists change in areas with increased refugee presence.

q17.value: I will measure candidates’ issue stances with data from voting advice application surveys (VAA’s), in which each candidate answers a long list of questions about political issues. The effects will be estimated using a difference-in-differences (DiD) design. This design allows me to establish whether a new reception centre has an effect on how candidates answer questions that relate to redistributive policies, immigration, and questions related to national identity and social values. The primary outcome variable of the study will be the potential change in candidates’ VAA responses between 2012 and 2017. Three different surveys will be used by three different media companies. The most important survey will be the nation-wide VAA survey of the Finnish Broadcasting Company YLE in 2017 (N=17858) and its counterpart of the 2012 municipal elections (N=20754). The other surveys will be the VAAs of the newspapers Helsingin Sanomat and Kainuun Sanomat. The study will trace how candidates who answered both surveys changed their opinions over time as a function of receiving or not receiving asylum seekers in 2015 in their municipalities. All the used data is public, and the candidates are anonymized in the used dataset.

q19.value: 295 municipalities, 17 858 out of a total of 33 618 candidates in the Finnish municipal elections in 2017

registration_responses.q5: This study has been generously funded by the Ella and Georg Ehrnrooth foundation as well as the Finnish Konkordia League.

The empirical analysis providing causal evidence for this puzzle has yielded partially contradicting results: Steinmayr (2016) established a decrease in the votes for the far-right in the geographic vicinity to asylum seekers in Austria whereas Dinas et al. (2018) showed an increase in the vote share for the Greek far right as a result of direct exposure to refugees. Instead of focusing just on voters, this article examines the political elite in Finland: what type of candidates run for office and how do candidates in municipal elections formulate their campaign promises and preferences for immigration and redistributive policies, and how do they answer questions on social values depending on their level of exposure to asylum seekers?

In particular, I will examine if candidates change their stances on immigration and the welfare state in districts with asylum seekers’ reception centres and how much electoral reward there is for such stance shifts. The central idea is to test whether it is contact theory (Allport 1954) or conflict theory (Collins 1974) at work, that is, do politicians become more compassionate or exclusive in their campaign promises in the geographical vicinity to refugees as well as how the composition of party lists change in areas with increased refugee presence.

The effects will be estimated using a difference-in-differences (DiD) design. This design allows me to establish whether a new reception centre has an effect on how candidates answer questions that relate to redistributive policies, immigration, and questions related to national identity and social values. The primary outcome variable of the study will be the potential change in candidates’ VAA responses between 2012 and 2017. Three different surveys will be used by three different media companies. attributes.title: Preferences Toward Globalization and Technology Policies

q1.value: Preferences Toward Globalization and Technology Policies

q5.value: I thank Mary Gallagher, Iain Osgood, Ted Brader, Jim Morrow, Noah Nathan, Kirill Zhirkov, and participants at the University of Michigan’s Comparative Politics Workshop for their suggestions and comments.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This study extends a previous observational study where I argue that individuals tend to misattribute blame for economic dislocations toward outgroups — immigrants and workers abroad — while discounting the effects of technology. Using the 2016 American National Elections Studies, a nationally representative survey, I show that workers facing higher risk of automation feel less secure about their jobs. However, workers at risk of automation are no more likely to support government spending to promote technology that might aid further automation. Instead, they are significantly more likely to oppose free trade agreements and immigration, even when controlling for standard explanations for these attitudes. The survey experiments outlined in the document seek to understand if and how information affects blame attribution and preferences toward government policies that aim at responding to globalization and automation-related labor market shocks. Examples of such policies include protectionism, incentives to onshore, financial assistance, and restrictions on technology. It also examines whether sources of job displacement affect support for basic income.

q17.value: Using a vignette design and a choice-based conjoint experiment. I prime individual to think about different causes of job displacement at a toy manufacturer by asking them to read a fictitious Reuters article. I randomly assign respondents to one of seven experimental conditions. In each of the treatments, respondents will read a fictitious news article about a made up company, Aiden Toy’s plan to close down its factories due to offshoring to China (T1), offshoring to Canada (T2), competition with cheap imports (T3), hiring of more immigrant workers (T4), automation (T5), or no specified reason/prime about job loss (T6). Only the heading and one body sentence are varied for most cases except for the control, where respondents read a “Company Spotlight” article about Aiden Toys, with the informational details preserved from the treatment conditions. I then measure their emotional responses to the article as well as their policy preferences. I use a choice-based conjoint experiment to study attitudes toward guaranteed basic income programs. I ask respondents to “[i]magine that the US government is launching a basic income program pilot. At the pilot stage, access to the program will be limited to individuals who had lost their jobs involuntarily in the past 3 years. Those in the basic income program will receive a fixed monthly payment from the government indefinitely. You will see a total of ten profiles of individuals, two will be displayed at a time. Which of the two individuals do you think should have priority access to the basic income program?”

registration_responses.q1: Preferences Toward Globalization and Technology Policies
registration_responses.q5: I thank Mary Gallagher, Iain Osgood, Ted Brader, Jim Morrow, Noah Nathan, Kirill Zhirkov, and participants at the University of Michigan’s Comparative Politics Workshop for their suggestions and comments.

Examples of such policies include protectionism, incentives to onshore, financial assistance, and restrictions on technology. It also examines whether sources of job displacement affect support for basic income.

Only the heading and one body sentence are varied for most cases except for the control, where respondents read a “Company Spotlight” article about Aiden Toys, with the informational details preserved from the treatment conditions. I then measure their emotional responses to the article as well as their policy preferences. I use a choice-based conjoint experiment to study attitudes toward guaranteed basic income programs. Those in the basic income program will receive a fixed monthly payment from the government indefinitely. You will see a total of ten profiles of individuals, two will be displayed at a time. Which of the two individuals do you think should have priority access to the basic income program?”

attributes.title: Who Likes Rebels? Representation and the Electoral Success of Parliamentary Mavericks

q1.value: Who Likes Rebels? Representation and the Electoral Success of Parliamentary Mavericks

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Why do candidates for political office draw attention to themselves by rebelling against the system they are part of? We implement a conjoint survey experiment on a national representative sample of the U.K. voting population. It elicits voters' perceptions of politicians who portray themselves as rebels with respect to their party. The study uncovers the value of rebellion to sitting Members of Parliament and helps to understand the conditions under which being a rebel is electorally advantageous. The abundance of rebellious rhetoric during electoral campaigns, as well as on the parliamentary floor, makes these questions of empirical and normative importance. Our study parses the different factors that make rebels appealing to voters by employing a conjoint-experimental design embedded in an online survey on a nationally representative sample of the UK population. It explicitly considers the party's reaction to rebels, the target of rebellion (e.g. against party, district opinion, or public opinion), while also triggering respondents' considerations of the norm of party discipline. The design allows us to determine when such rebellious strategies are most effective and whether they undermine democratic representation in the eyes of the electorate.  Survey respondents choose between two hypothetical candidates who are characterized by a range of characteristics (e.g. rebellion and tenure in parliament).  The survey instrument randomly assigns which characteristics participants see (5 out of a list of 9), the exact realization of these characteristics, and which political issue is the object of rebellious activity (immigration or taxation/spending; issue treatment). We also randomize whether the conjoint table is preceded by a text that reminds respondents that MPs usually vote with their party (party discipline treatment). This set-up generates a conjoint experiment embedded in a two-by-two treatment design (see attachment):   Table 1: 2x2 treatment design embedded in the introductory text preceding the conjoint table     Immigration Taxation/Spending No party discipline prime Parliament voted on a bill that would affect the levels of immigration. People have different opinions about what their Member of Parliament should do Parliament voted on a bill that would affect the levels of taxes and government spending. People have different opinions about what their Member of Parliament should do Party discipline prime Parliament voted on a bill that would affect the levels of immigration. People have different opinions about what their Member of Parliament should do, but usually MPs support the position of their party Parliament voted on a bill that would affect the levels of taxes and government spending. People have different opinions about what their Member of Parliament should do, but usually MPs support the position of their party   Outcome measures are a feeling thermometer score (0-100) for each MP and vote choice between MP1 and MP2. Outcome measures are elicited after each of the six vignettes shown to each respondent.

q16.value: Literature finds a preference for MPs who dissents against their party in legislative votes. We test three mechanism that explain such behavior by voters: H1: Voters appreciate rebellious activity when it suits public opinion. H2: Voters prefer rebellious MPs when their activity conforms with their constituents’ preferences. H3: Voters value rebellious MPs because they push diverging ideas for the benefit of the party and not just help the party leadership to achieve its goals. We further will also evaluate existing claims in the literature about the moderating effect of various variables on voters’ preference for a rebellious MP. - Whether the MP was pivotal in the legislative vote case presented to respondents - Whether the MP deviates in his/her position towards the center or the extreme - Whether the MP’s vote was congruent or opposed to UKIPs’ announced preference

q17.value: Estimating the effect of candidates' attributes such as rebellious activity on vote choice, we estimate the relative importance of one attribute assigned to the candidates over others. Specifically, following Hainmueller et al (2014), we estimate the Average Marginal Component Effect (AMCE). Testing H1, we compare the AMCE of rebellious activity on vote preference and feeling thermometer scores when public opinion aligns with the MP’s vote to when it does not. Similarly, to assess H2, we compare the AMCE of rebellious activity on vote preference and feeling thermometer scores when the opinion of MP’s constituent aligns with the MP’s vote to when it does not. Finally, we compute the difference in AMCE of rebellious activity on outcome measures in baseline vs party discipline treatment to evaluate H3.

registration_responses.q1: Who Likes Rebels? Representation and the Electoral Success of Parliamentary Mavericks
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

We implement a conjoint survey experiment on a national representative sample of the U.K. voting population. It elicits voters' perceptions of politicians who portray themselves as rebels with respect to their party. The study uncovers the value of rebellion to sitting Members of Parliament and helps to understand the conditions under which being a rebel is electorally advantageous. The abundance of rebellious rhetoric during electoral campaigns, as well as on the parliamentary floor, makes these questions of empirical and normative importance. Our study parses the different factors that make rebels appealing to voters by employing a conjoint-experimental design embedded in an online survey on a nationally representative sample of the UK population. It explicitly considers the party's reaction to rebels, the target of rebellion (e.g. against party, district opinion, or public opinion), while also triggering respondents' considerations of the norm of party discipline. The design allows us to determine when such rebellious strategies are most effective and whether they undermine democratic representation in the eyes of the electorate.  Survey respondents choose between two hypothetical candidates who are characterized by a range of characteristics (e.g. rebellion and tenure in parliament).  The survey instrument randomly assigns which characteristics participants see (5 out of a list of 9), the exact realization of these characteristics, and which political issue is the object of rebellious activity (immigration or taxation/spending; issue treatment). We also randomize whether the conjoint table is preceded by a text that reminds respondents that MPs usually vote with their party (party discipline treatment). This set-up generates a conjoint experiment embedded in a two-by-two treatment design (see attachment):   Table 1: 2x2 treatment design embedded in the introductory text preceding the conjoint table     Immigration Taxation/Spending No party discipline prime Parliament voted on a bill that would affect the levels of immigration. People have different opinions about what their Member of Parliament should do Parliament voted on a bill that would affect the levels of taxes and government spending. Outcome measures are elicited after each of the six vignettes shown to each respondent.

We test three mechanism that explain such behavior by voters: H1: Voters appreciate rebellious activity when it suits public opinion. H2: Voters prefer rebellious MPs when their activity conforms with their constituents’ preferences. H3: Voters value rebellious MPs because they push diverging ideas for the benefit of the party and not just help the party leadership to achieve its goals. We further will also evaluate existing claims in the literature about the moderating effect of various variables on voters’ preference for a rebellious MP. - Whether the MP was pivotal in the legislative vote case presented to respondents - Whether the MP deviates in his/her position towards the center or the extreme - Whether the MP’s vote was congruent or opposed to UKIPs’ announced preference

Specifically, following Hainmueller et al (2014), we estimate the Average Marginal Component Effect (AMCE). Testing H1, we compare the AMCE of rebellious activity on vote preference and feeling thermometer scores when public opinion aligns with the MP’s vote to when it does not. Similarly, to assess H2, we compare the AMCE of rebellious activity on vote preference and feeling thermometer scores when the opinion of MP’s constituent aligns with the MP’s vote to when it does not. Finally, we compute the difference in AMCE of rebellious activity on outcome measures in baseline vs party discipline treatment to evaluate H3.

attributes.title: Detained Immigrants and Parole Decisions: Does Legal Aid Make a Difference?

q1.value: Detained Immigrants and Parole Decisions: Does Legal Aid Make a Difference?

q2.value: Daniel E. Chand | Daniel P. Hawes | Christopher P. Banks | M Apolonia Calderon

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Immigration legal proceedings are highly complicated civil proceedings, although commonly misunderstood as criminal proceedings. Immigrants with detention hearings are not entitled to an attorney if they cannot afford one. While nonprofits attempt to help low-income immigrants, they struggle with scarce resources. Additionally, legal scholars and social scientists provide no clear answers on whether legal aid is even effective (Poppe and Rachlinski 2016). We are conducting a pilot study which consists of a random assignment field experiment and follow-up in-person interview to examine the effects of legal aid in immigration parole hearings for asylum applicants (asylees). In the pilot study, we seek to determine what impact legal assistance has on parole adjudications. Parole adjudications are “paper hearings” conducted by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents. These are informal adjudications with no physical hearing or oral testimony. Instead, arguments in support of granting parole are presented by written arguments and documentation (Schreckhise 2015). Although the outcomes such hearings greatly affect the lives of individuals, applicants are not entitled to legal assistance if they cannot afford to pay for it.

q16.value: This study is designed to demonstrate the impact of legal assistance in parole adjudications, which are “paper hearings” conducted by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents in the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS). Based on the scope of the relevant social science and law literature cited below, we hypothesize that: H1: Receiving legal assistance significantly increases the likelihood of detained asylum applicants receiving parole. H2: Receiving legal assistance will significantly reduce the wait time to receive a parole determination from ICE.

q17.value: This mixed-methods field research project consists of two parts: 1) a random assignment legal-aid experiment with asylees applying for parole; and 2) follow-up interviews with International Institute of Akron (IIA) legal staff and a selection of asylee participants. The location is the CoreCivic’s Northeast Ohio Correctional Center in Youngstown, Ohio. Through our partnership with IIA, we are randomly assigning subjects to two groups: 1) those receiving pro-bono legal assistance with their parole application; and. 2) those without legal assistance in applying for parole. IIA attorneys present potential subjects with a consent form explaining the nature of the research project.^1 IIA passes the individual’s name and case number to researchers who use a random number generator to determine group assignment. A random number generator, with 50/50 odds, assigns the individual to one of two groups: Group 1: The individual receives a pro-bono attorney to assist the asylee with a parole application. Group 2: The individual is assigned to the non-attorney group and receives a $40 commissary card. The commissary card can be used to make phone calls, which can help the applicant collect evidence for a parole petition. Group 2 is also provided a list of local immigration legal-aid groups. Due to recent changes in federal policy, ICE is required by law to issue a parole determination for everyone, even if they specifically do not put forward a formal petition. We have access to the determinations through the IIA attorneys for Group 1 and Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request for Group 2. Exactly 30 days after we have reached our targeted in-take (30 signed consent forms for both groups) we will begin our follow-up check-ins for Group 2, which allows us to determine if any of these individuals obtained legal aid aside from IIA (potential crossover influence).^2 It is also at this time we will intend to FOIA ICE for the 30 Group 2 determinations.^3 Researchers use the notification documents to create our two outcome measures and compare parole determinations and the time it took to receive them across the two levels. The results, we believe, will demonstrate that receiving legal assistance will increase the likelihood of 1) a successful parole application; and, 2) reducing the time for ICE to issue the determination. Because the ICE parole determination contains an “issued” date and we know exactly when each subject was originally detained at Youngstown by our initial meeting and consent form, we will know exactly the number of days the individual waited for a parole determination from ICE (our second dependent variable). We will begin contacting individuals for the in-depth semi-structured interviews 30 days after our targeted in-take goal. We intend to conduct 20 interviews with subjects (10 for each group) and interviews with the legal staff at IIA. Our inquiry into the effects of representation goes beyond focusing solely on the effect it exerts on the outcome of the parole hearings. These interviews provide a holistic understanding of how representation provides immigrants with agency to exercise their rights and alleviates marginalization within legal proceedings. We will also be able to assess the attorneys’ and participants’ perceptions of how race and ethnicity, and being a “non-member” of the U.S. community, affects their treatment in the legal system, thus making additional contributions to membership theory and crimmingration literatures. Additionally, the interviews provide a way to explore best practices for immigrant-serving nonprofits from both the perspective of the organizational representative and the client. Our IIA legal staff interviews will consist of two staff attorneys, one Board of Immigration Appeals (BIA) accredited representative, and one Immigrant Justice Coordinator (IJC) legal assistant, along with the executive director (ED).^4 Interviews help to understand the effect that representation has on exercising rights in a process that does not allow physical or oral testimony. Therefore, our interviews begin with asking questions to uncover and connect themes across the various cases in our sample of study. Our sample of immigrants without legal representation through IIA will be asked similar questions about their agency in the process and their understanding of the legal procedures and outcomes. For legal staff, our semi-structured interviews will focus on understanding their interactions with the ICE agents and with their clients, focusing on patterns they have seen which have remained similar or changed over time. Additionally, our set of interview questions will further seek to understand how they view their role in helping immigrants apart from just providing legal assistance and representation. By being able to interview most of the parties in the parole hearing process, we will be able to unpack the effects of representation from legal outcomes to the ways that representation helps create agency for a marginalized community with limited political rights, especially during an era of hyper crimmigration (Stumpf 2006) that often presumes immigrants are guilty until proven innocent. Once all interviews have been completed and transcribed, we will use a theoretical thematic analysis that focuses on detecting trends across interviews. The theoretical framework we use supports our random assignment experiment and should develop nonprofit theory on service delivery to vulnerable populations. We will also draw best practices by focusing on themes of what asylees lacked, in terms of aid, and what they felt were the best interactions they had with IIA. 1: English and Spanish consent forms available upon request. 2: We stress, individuals assigned to Group 2 may obtain legal assistance on their own. Indeed, in addition to building on the scholarly literature on the effects of legal representation, the project’s ultimate goal is to help nonprofits by determining whether legal aid is effective in such circumstances. However, we would also add it would be highly unusual for a detained asylee at Youngstown to obtain legal aid for a parole application aside from any pro-bono assistance provided by IIA, but the authors will be checking with each Group 2 subject to document for the purpose of crossover. 3: A copy of an ICE’s parole notification form, used to create our dependent variables, is included as Appendix A. 4: The ED is also an attorney. See IIA’s staff members: https://www.iiakron.org/our-team (accessed Feb. 28, 2019).

q19.value: Group 1 (receiving legal assistance) = 30 subjects; Group 2 (control, commissary card) = 30 subjects; anticipate 20 total in-person follow-up interviews: 10 from Group 1 and 10 from Group 2; also interview 5 members of IIA's legal staff

q27.value: Legal aid is provided by staff attorneys at the International Institute of Akron (IIA).

registration_responses.q1: Detained Immigrants and Parole Decisions: Does Legal Aid Make a Difference?
registration_responses.q2: Daniel E. Chand | Daniel P. Hawes | Christopher P. Banks | M Apolonia Calderon
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities
registration_responses.q15: Immigration legal proceedings are highly complicated civil proceedings, although commonly misunderstood as criminal proceedings. Immigrants with detention hearings are not entitled to an attorney if they cannot afford one. While nonprofits attempt to help low-income immigrants, they struggle with scarce resources. Additionally, legal scholars and social scientists provide no clear answers on whether legal aid is even effective (Poppe and Rachlinski 2016). We are conducting a pilot study which consists of a random assignment field experiment and follow-up in-person interview to examine the effects of legal aid in immigration parole hearings for asylum applicants (asylees). In the pilot study, we seek to determine what impact legal assistance has on parole adjudications. Parole adjudications are “paper hearings” conducted by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents. These are informal adjudications with no physical hearing or oral testimony. Instead, arguments in support of granting parole are presented by written arguments and documentation (Schreckhise 2015). Although the outcomes such hearings greatly affect the lives of individuals, applicants are not entitled to legal assistance if they cannot afford to pay for it.
registration_responses.q16: This study is designed to demonstrate the impact of legal assistance in parole adjudications, which are “paper hearings” conducted by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents in the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS). Based on the scope of the relevant social science and law literature cited below, we hypothesize that: H1: Receiving legal assistance significantly increases the likelihood of detained asylum applicants receiving parole. H2: Receiving legal assistance will significantly reduce the wait time to receive a parole determination from ICE.
registration_responses.q17: This mixed-methods field research project consists of two parts: 1) a random assignment legal-aid experiment with asylees applying for parole; and 2) follow-up interviews with International Institute of Akron (IIA) legal staff and a selection of asylee participants. The location is the CoreCivic’s Northeast Ohio Correctional Center in Youngstown, Ohio. Through our partnership with IIA, we are randomly assigning subjects to two groups: 1) those receiving pro-bono legal assistance with their parole application; and. 2) those without legal assistance in applying for parole. IIA attorneys present potential subjects with a consent form explaining the nature of the research project.^1 IIA passes the individual’s name and case number to researchers who use a random number generator to determine group assignment. A random number generator, with 50/50 odds, assigns the individual to one of two groups: Group 1: The individual receives a pro-bono attorney to assist the asylee with a parole application. Group 2: The individual is assigned to the non-attorney group and receives a $40 commissary card. The commissary card can be used to make phone calls, which can help the applicant collect evidence for a parole petition. Group 2 is also provided a list of local immigration legal-aid groups. Due to recent changes in federal policy, ICE is required by law to issue a parole determination for everyone, even if they specifically do not put forward a formal petition. We have access to the determinations through the IIA attorneys for Group 1 and Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request for Group 2. Exactly 30 days after we have reached our targeted in-take (30 signed consent forms for both groups) we will begin our follow-up check-ins for Group 2, which allows us to determine if any of these individuals obtained legal aid aside from IIA (potential crossover influence).^2 It is also at this time we will intend to FOIA ICE for the 30 Group 2 determinations.^3 Researchers use the notification documents to create our two outcome measures and compare parole determinations and the time it took to receive them across the two levels. The results, we believe, will demonstrate that receiving legal assistance will increase the likelihood of 1) a successful parole application; and, 2) reducing the time for ICE to issue the determination. Because the ICE parole determination contains an “issued” date and we know exactly when each subject was originally detained at Youngstown by our initial meeting and consent form, we will know exactly the number of days the individual waited for a parole determination from ICE (our second dependent variable). We will begin contacting individuals for the in-depth semi-structured interviews 30 days after our targeted in-take goal. We intend to conduct 20 interviews with subjects (10 for each group) and interviews with the legal staff at IIA. Our inquiry into the effects of representation goes beyond focusing solely on the effect it exerts on the outcome of the parole hearings. These interviews provide a holistic understanding of how representation provides immigrants with agency to exercise their rights and alleviates marginalization within legal proceedings. We will also be able to assess the attorneys’ and participants’ perceptions of how race and ethnicity, and being a “non-member” of the U.S. community, affects their treatment in the legal system, thus making additional contributions to membership theory and crimmingration literatures. Additionally, the interviews provide a way to explore best practices for immigrant-serving nonprofits from both the perspective of the organizational representative and the client. Our IIA legal staff interviews will consist of two staff attorneys, one Board of Immigration Appeals (BIA) accredited representative, and one Immigrant Justice Coordinator (IJC) legal assistant, along with the executive director (ED).^4 Interviews help to understand the effect that representation has on exercising rights in a process that does not allow physical or oral testimony. Therefore, our interviews begin with asking questions to uncover and connect themes across the various cases in our sample of study. Our sample of immigrants without legal representation through IIA will be asked similar questions about their agency in the process and their understanding of the legal procedures and outcomes. For legal staff, our semi-structured interviews will focus on understanding their interactions with the ICE agents and with their clients, focusing on patterns they have seen which have remained similar or changed over time. Additionally, our set of interview questions will further seek to understand how they view their role in helping immigrants apart from just providing legal assistance and representation. By being able to interview most of the parties in the parole hearing process, we will be able to unpack the effects of representation from legal outcomes to the ways that representation helps create agency for a marginalized community with limited political rights, especially during an era of hyper crimmigration (Stumpf 2006) that often presumes immigrants are guilty until proven innocent. Once all interviews have been completed and transcribed, we will use a theoretical thematic analysis that focuses on detecting trends across interviews. The theoretical framework we use supports our random assignment experiment and should develop nonprofit theory on service delivery to vulnerable populations. We will also draw best practices by focusing on themes of what asylees lacked, in terms of aid, and what they felt were the best interactions they had with IIA. 1: English and Spanish consent forms available upon request. 2: We stress, individuals assigned to Group 2 may obtain legal assistance on their own. Indeed, in addition to building on the scholarly literature on the effects of legal representation, the project’s ultimate goal is to help nonprofits by determining whether legal aid is effective in such circumstances. However, we would also add it would be highly unusual for a detained asylee at Youngstown to obtain legal aid for a parole application aside from any pro-bono assistance provided by IIA, but the authors will be checking with each Group 2 subject to document for the purpose of crossover. 3: A copy of an ICE’s parole notification form, used to create our dependent variables, is included as Appendix A. 4: The ED is also an attorney. See IIA’s staff members: https://www.iiakron.org/our-team (accessed Feb. 28, 2019).
registration_responses.q19: Group 1 (receiving legal assistance) = 30 subjects; Group 2 (control, commissary card) = 30 subjects; anticipate 20 total in-person follow-up interviews: 10 from Group 1 and 10 from Group 2; also interview 5 members of IIA's legal staff
registration_responses.q27: Legal aid is provided by staff attorneys at the International Institute of Akron (IIA).

attributes.title: Role of Public Media in Rhetoric and Propaganda: Evidence from Survey Experiments in Japan

q1.value: Role of Public Media in Rhetoric and Propaganda: Evidence from Survey Experiments in Japan

q2.value: Seiki Tanaka | Atsushi Tago | Taka-aki Asano

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: A growing number of studies examine rhetoric and propaganda in authoritarian states, in particular China, but little is known about their origin and effects in a democratic state. We examine the impact of rhetoric and propaganda on citizens’ attitudes in Japan where the administration is allegedly stepping up control of media. A focus on a democratic country also allows us to consider different types of media, and in particular, examine how propaganda by public and private media influence citizens differently.

q16.value: Within the context of Japan, there is a widespread belief that public media (Nippon Hoso Kyokai or NHK) should offer politically neutral coverage and be independent of the government's position. We take advantage of the perceived neutrality principle of the public media and propose to the following main hypotheses. Please note that we have divergent hypotheses based on two underlying mechanisms we consider: backfire and trusting: - Those who are exposed to propaganda from public media are more or less likely to worsen their attitudes towards media and the government than those in the control group. - Those who are exposed to propaganda from left-leaning private media are more or less likely to worsen their attitudes towards the media and the government than those in the control group. - Those who are exposed to propaganda from right-leaning private media are more or less likely to hold similar attitudes towards the media and the government as those in the control group. - The above-mentioned treatment effects are larger for those whose perception about each media matches the societal perception than those whose view does not match. - Those who are high in social dominance orientation may tend to endorse propaganda and they are thus more likely to experience the trusting mechanism than those who are low in social dominance orientation.

q17.value: To test the hypotheses, we conduct a survey in Japan in August 2019. We employ a vignette experiment in which we randomize two components: 1) propaganda and 2) types of media. As for dependent variables, we consider three sets of variables: 1) evaluation of the government and its policies; 2) evaluation of media; and 3) behavioral questions. For the first group of the variables, we ask three different questions: 1) trust in the government; 2) support levels for war-related questions (i.e., apology for the past wars; an alternative facility for war remembrance; prime minister's visit to Yasukuni shrine); and 3) evaluation of the Abe administration's foreign policy. For the second group, we ask respondents whether they find the propaganda information credible as well as their trust in NHK, left-leaning, and right-leaning media. Lastly, as our behavioral questions, we ask respondents whether they would join in 1) anti-Abe's foreign policy demonstrations and 2) anti-China demonstrations.

registration_responses.q1: Role of Public Media in Rhetoric and Propaganda: Evidence from Survey Experiments in Japan

Please note that we have divergent hypotheses based on two underlying mechanisms we consider: backfire and trusting: - Those who are exposed to propaganda from public media are more or less likely to worsen their attitudes towards media and the government than those in the control group. - Those who are exposed to propaganda from left-leaning private media are more or less likely to worsen their attitudes towards the media and the government than those in the control group. - Those who are exposed to propaganda from right-leaning private media are more or less likely to hold similar attitudes towards the media and the government as those in the control group. - The above-mentioned treatment effects are larger for those whose perception about each media matches the societal perception than those whose view does not match. - Those who are high in social dominance orientation may tend to endorse propaganda and they are thus more likely to experience the trusting mechanism than those who are low in social dominance orientation.

attributes.title: Colorism and the latent race cleavage in Mexico Evidence from an Online experiment

q1.value: Colorism and the latent race cleavage in Mexico Evidence from an Online experiment

q2.value: Mario Luca | Lucia Motolinia Carballo | José Maria Rodriguez Valadez

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Race (or skin color) have been not considered a salient political cleavage in Mexico since the post-revolutionary, nation-making idea of mestizaje (intermingling of races) claimed that there is a Mexican race created by mestizos. However, we argue that voters have heterogenous race-based preferences that are rooted in a latent race identity, conditional on their party preferences. To test this argument, we seek to implement an online experiment during the 2018 elections for Governor of Mexico City. The treatment corresponds to photographs of the candidates, in which the relative darkness/lightness of the candidate in the photograph was manipulated to accentuate racial cues. More in detail, we seek to recruit participants through an advertisement on Twitter for an online survey. Participants that agree to participate will be sampled into treatment and control groups and invited to participate in our survey where they will be exposed to our treatment/control picture. In addition, the survey will investigate whether participants exposed to different pictures when the darkness/lightness of the candidate was altered have different attitudes towards the candidates.

q16.value: We aim to test the following hypotheses: 1. Pigmentocracy Bias: there is a hierarchy of skin colors where lighter skin tones are at the top. Therefore, we expect that regardless of the ideology and skin color of the voter, everyone will prefer lighter skin candidates. 2. In-group identification bias: skin tone can be a cue for in-group identification. Hence, we expect people to perceive alike-looking candidates as more representative of their social group. Therefore, if skin colors are important cues in the Mexican contest, we expect that people will prefer closer-looking candidates. 3. Ideological bias: race not being a salient dimension in Mexican political agenda, we have no reason to believe that ideology per se accounts for differences in support derived from treatment. 4. In-group ideological awakening: Our main hypothesis is that in-group bias is moderated by ideology. Since there is an overlap of class and race in Mexico, with darker-skinned voters overrepresented at lower socioeconomic positions, when the ideological agendas of parties cater to certain social classes and further the assortment of class and parties, indirectly they enhance the sorting of skin-tones and parties. Thus, we expect voters to have heterogeneous skin color-based preferences that is conditional on their ideological inclinations and is rooted in their race identity.

q17.value: Our experiment relies on survey-data on political preferences of Twitter users, as well as many relevant covariates. In particular, we ask about participants’ attitude towards the candidates for Mexico City Mayor and to rank them according to certain attributes. Having randomized our treatment -a lighter/darker picture of one of the candidates-, we can compare the average answers between treatments to measure whether changing skin color of candidates modifies people’s opinions in the ways described in the hypothesis section.

registration_responses.q1: Colorism and the latent race cleavage in Mexico Evidence from an Online experiment

registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities

attributes.title: Testing Legislator Responsiveness to Citizens and Firms in the Vietnamese National Assembly: A Field Experiment

q1.value: Testing Legislator Responsiveness to Citizens and Firms in the Vietnamese National Assembly: A Field Experiment

q2.value: Edmund Malesky | Anh Le | Anh Tran | Jason Todd

q5.value: Funded by Jameel Poverty Action Lab, Governance Initiative

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Our project aims to establish whether targeted provision of constituent preferences increases the responsiveness of delegates to the Vietnamese National Assembly (VNA). In the first stage of our randomized control trial (RCT), we assign legislators to one of three groups: (1) those receiving infographics about the preferences of citizens within their province; (2) those receiving infographics about the preferences of local firms; and (3) a control group receiving no treatment. Following this informational treatment, we survey legislators about their views and the views of their constituents regarding the upcoming education law. Delegates’ responsiveness to constituents will be responses to a survey administered by the VNA library. The second stage of the RCT is a dose-response design, where we assign each province a treatment dosage, i.e. the fraction of delegates from a province receiving an informational treatment. We measure the responsiveness of delegates at the provincial level through mentions of the information during (1) internal, pre-debate provincial caucuses and (2) VNA floor debates.

q16.value: (H0) Null Hypothesis: Delegates will be unresponsive to the concerns of any constituency: RBusinesses ≈ RCitizens ≈ RControl. (H1) Delegates receiving the citizen information treatment will exhibit greater responsiveness than those receiving the firm information treatment; and those receiving the business treatment will be more responsive than the control group: RCitizens > RBusinesses > RControl. (H2) Delegates receiving the citizen information treatment; and those receiving the citizen treatment will not be significantly more responsive than the control group. RBusinesses > RCitizens ≈ RControl. (H3) Delegates receiving the information treatment for both firms and citizens will be statistically indistinguishable, however, both types of delegates will be significantly more responsive than the control group. RBusinesses ≈ RCitizens > RControl. (H4) Saturation: The greater the level of treatment saturation in a province, the higher probability that delegates from the province will speak on the house floor; the greater the number of speeches from each delegates; and the more speeches

q17.value: Please see our attached Pre-Analysis Plan

q27.value: Researchers, We designed treatments, but they were delivered by the Vietnam National Economic University’s Institute for Policy and Management (PIMP). The survey was delivered by the National Assembly Library Office.
